thread.title: Trump team bashed media's attention to terrorism; here's how The News played it
thread.title_full: Trump team bashed media's attention to terrorism; here's how The News played it

author: Claire Z. Cardona
title: Trump team bashed media's attention to terrorism; here's how The News played it
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
To bolster President Donald Trump's claim that the news media fails to cover terrorist attacks, the White House issued a list of 78 attacks ​that it argues were underreported. 
"​In many cases, the very, very dishonest press does not want to report it," Trump said Monday while addressing U.S. service members. "They [the press] have their reasons, and you understand that." 
The ​White House ​list included ​several high-profile attacks in the U.S. and abroad, some close​​ to home such as the attack at the Curtis Culwell Center in Garland in May 2015. 
Of the 78 incidents on the list, ​ The Dallas Morning News covered 61 of them in print and online. Trump's spokesman Sean Spicer said Trump did not mean that the incidents got no coverage ​but that they did not get ​the same attention as other events. 
"Like a protest gets blown out of the water, and yet an attack or a foiled attack doesn't necessarily get the same coverage," Spicer said.​​ 
Excluded from the list were attacks in countries that have been most devastated by terrorism, including Iraq, Nigeria and Syria. 
The News had coverage of a number of attacks in those strife-torn nations, such as the massive bombing in Baghdad on July 4 that killed 175 people and wounded almost 200. The White House did not explain why those countries were omitted. 
The ​list of attacks was described as "executed or inspired by" the so-called Islamic State. 
Fifteen of those stories ran on the front page of The News . Some — such as San Bernardino, the 2015 Paris attacks and the Pulse nightclub massacre in Orlando​ — took up much of the front page for days ​on end. 
Some stories — such as the Garland and Pulse shootings, the Paris attacks and ​a ​student who drove through a crowd in Columbus, Ohio — were paired with coverage of the local ​reaction. Dallas' LGBT community preaches love after Orlando shooting: 'We need a dose of Jesus in the world today' 
Thirty-three of the 78 received more than one day of coverage, and stories are still being produced on some of the incidents. 
​For example, ​ The News continues to follow the trial and sentencing of a man linked to the two men who were killed after opening fire outside the Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Garland. 
A search of archives turned up only 17 incidents that ​ T​he News did not include in its print coverage. Five of those incidents resulted in deaths. Some included injuries, such as a Danish citizen wounded in a shooting in Saudi Arabia, and others did not involve casualties. 
One shooting where two people were supposedly injured is described as a January 2016 "drive-by shooting outside a hotel frequented by tourists." An Al-Jazeera report on what appears to be the same attack cited no injuries. 
One incident that details a Molotov cocktail attack on a mosque and community center in Malmo, Sweden, was ruled a minor arson incident and not terrorism. 
In another incident, police ruled that a knife attack in ​​Queensland​, Australia -- which ended with two dead and one wounded -- was not linked to extremism, though a romantic relationship may have factored into the attack. 
Though some of the 47 incidents ran in ​ The News' inside pages as brief stories taking up several lines, others were featured prominently as centerpieces on the World and Nation pages. 
One such story ​reported on a man opening fire on a Philadelphia police officer in January 2016. 
Yet another incident — the bombings in New York City and New Jersey — started as a shorter story when little information was available. By day three, the suspects' arrest made up much of the front page of the paper. 
The Associated Press contributed to this report.
